contentfulBlogPost.title: Homelessness among Canada's Indigenous peoples: an issue fueled by injustices

Aboriginal homelessness in Canada: a literature review

In 2008, former Prime Minister of Canada Stephen Harper made an apology on behalf of the Canadian government to the Indigenous peoples of Canada regarding their treatment in Residential schools. Over a decade prior, the last Residential school - a government funded institution run by the Catholic Church to “assimilate” the Indigenous populations of Canada founded after Confederation - had closed. Indigenous children were kidnapped from their families and sent thousands of miles away to these “schools'', in which they were stripped of their native language, culture, and Indigenous identity.

Harper’s issued apology was viewed as the first step towards finding reconciliation and healing for the victims who experienced sexual and physical abuse within these institutions; however, little action has been taken with regards to the continued marginalization experienced by the Indigenous peoples of Canada. This is where the discussion of Indigenous homelessness takes place, as Indigenous peoples face discrimination and have a significantly different experience when it comes to homelessness.
Residential schools contributed to homelessness today

Firstly, Indigenous homelessness is better described and understood through Indigenous worldviews. These worldviews include individuals, families and communities isolated from their relationships to land, water, place, kin, each other, animals, cultures, languages and identities. Within the Canadian context, homelessness is confined to four categories -
Unsheltered, Emergency Sheltered, Provisionally Accommodated
and
At Risk of Homelessness.

While these four categories relate to the current circumstances of limited affordable housing and other socioeconomic issues, Indigenous homelessness takes into account the historical context of racism and displacement faced by First Nations, Métis and Inuit Peoples from their traditional governance and lands. Thus, the Canadian government’s establishment and funding of Residential schools contributed heavily to Indigenous homelessness, as the active effort to unravel their culture, society and traditions (cultural genocide) has left many First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Peoples within a state of generational trauma.
What are Indigenous viewpoints on homelessness?

As articulated by Indigenous Peoples, there are twelve dimensions of Indigenous homelessness. These dimensions are tied to colonization, and how Indigenous minds, bodies, and lands have been colonized. They include
overcrowding
homelessness,
historic displacement
homelessness,
mental disruption
and
imbalance
homelessness,
escaping or evading
harm homelessness, and
climate refuge
homelessness. Some of these dimensions sound familiar and are also experienced by Canadians, but these have all been placed into the Indigenous perspective.
Understanding the intersectionality of Indigenous homelessness is a vital step towards addressing the ways in which homelessness impacts Indigenous Peoples

. For example, overcrowding within the Indigenous context highlights the lack of affordable housing within Indigenous communities, as Indigenous households exceed the number of persons per dwelling compared to the average Canadian household in urban and rural communities. This overcrowding results in unsafe and unhealthy living conditions, where individuals feel the need to turn to homelessness.
What is also important to address is the narrative of Indigenous Peoples always being portrayed as traumatized, poor and sickly individuals

. There is little coverage of Indigenous women who have overcome circumstances such as poverty, homelessness, addiction or trauma. As well, within academic literature, there is a homogenization that takes place when it comes to describing and categorizing Canadian Indigenous populations.
Not every Indigenous population, group, or community experiences homelessness the same way

. There is significant diversity that takes place, and addressing that while there may be similarities, it is important to distinguish the fact every Indigenous population is different and has unique experiences.
Ongoing injustices and inequalities continue to contribute to homelessness

Overall, it is clear that the apology made by Harper on behalf of Canada has remained what it stood as thirteen years ago - simply words. And since Harper, empty promises have been made to combat issues that impact Indigenous communities, such as the high number of missing and murdered Indigenous women, insane Northern food prices, and lack of clean water. The severe lack of care for Canada’s Indigenous Peoples is a key contributor to ongoing homelessness in their communities. This also highlights the ways in which intersectionality plays a significant part in someone’s life. Social and societal issues impact people in different ways, and taking into consideration these multiple perspectives and experiences faced by a racially marginalized population aids society when discussing ways in which to help these unique communities.
References
Patrick, C. (2014).
Aboriginal homelessness in Canada: a literature review
. Canadian Homelessness Research Network Press.
Thistle, Jesse A.
Definition of Indigenous Homelessness in Canada
. Canadian Observatory on Homelessness, 2017.
